text: They're trying now to be the leader who everyone loves, but what really needs to happen very often is, we need to drive towards results. This employee continuing to not really do a great job at their job, you don't want to push them because you don't want to upset them. You don't want to give them difficult feedback, so you're just going to keep hoping it works out. Ultimately, that leads to the demise of your company.
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: Lenny asks Alisa about her advice that a leader's job is not to make employees happy. Alisa explains that many founders and leaders, especially those new to management, mistakenly prioritize keeping everyone happy over driving business results. She describes how this misguided approach leads to avoiding difficult conversations and performance issues, ultimately harming the company's success.
text_ko: 지금 모두가 사랑하는 리더가 되려고 노력하고 있지만, 사실 우리가 정말로 해야 하는 것은 결과를 이끌어내는 거예요. 이 직원이 계속해서 일을 잘 하지 못하는데, 그 사람을 밀어붙이기 싫어서 힘든 피드백을 주지 않으려는 경우가 많죠. 그래서 그냥 잘 되길 바라는 것만으로는 안 돼요. 결국, 이런 태도가 회사의 몰락으로 이어질 수 있어요.
text_zh: 他们现在试图成为大家都喜欢的领导，但实际上更需要的是，我们必须专注于结果。这个员工在工作中表现不佳，你不想给他们施加压力，因为你不想让他们不高兴。你也不想给他们带来困难的反馈，因此你只是希望事情能好转。最终，这会导致公司的衰败。
text_es: Están tratando de ser el líder que todos aman, pero lo que realmente necesita suceder con frecuencia es que debemos enfocarnos en los resultados. Este empleado que sigue sin desempeñar bien su trabajo, no quieres presionarlo porque no quieres molestarlo. No quieres darle retroalimentación difícil, así que simplemente seguirás esperando que las cosas se resuelvan. En última instancia, eso lleva a la caída de tu empresa.

text: Hope for the future is so important. I know this is going to be challenging for you to hear, not going to promote you, but I want you to know this. It's really important to me that you're able to succeed in your career here, and so I want to continue to help you find opportunities to build your skills and to advance.
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: Lenny asks Alisa for advice on having difficult conversations during performance review season, specifically when telling someone they won't get a promotion they expected. Alisa provides a script for delivering this disappointing news while maintaining hope and showing care for the employee's future development. She emphasizes the importance of painting a path forward rather than just delivering bad news.
text_ko: 미래에 대한 희망은 정말 중요해요. 이 말을 듣기 힘들 수도 있다는 걸 알아요. 승진은 없겠지만, 이 점은 꼭 알고 있었으면 해요. 당신이 여기서 경력을 쌓는 게 저에게 정말 중요하고, 그래서 계속해서 당신이 기술을 쌓고 발전할 수 있는 기회를 찾는 데 도와주고 싶어요.
text_zh: 对未来的希望非常重要。我知道这对你来说可能很难接受，我不会给你晋升，但我希望你明白这一点。对我来说，你在这里的职业成功非常重要，因此我希望继续帮助你寻找机会，以提升你的技能和职业发展。
text_es: La esperanza en el futuro es fundamental. Sé que esto puede ser difícil de escuchar, no te voy a promover, pero quiero que lo sepas. Me importa mucho que puedas tener éxito en tu carrera aquí, y por eso quiero seguir ayudándote a encontrar oportunidades para desarrollar tus habilidades y avanzar.

text: What I want to say to everybody is, sometimes you need to have patience and sometimes you need to look at the process. And I think you, as the leader, need to have the wisdom to know the difference, but also your finger on the pulse to recognize, is this an issue with patience or an issue with process?
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: Alisa shares a story about working with a CEO whose product launch kept getting delayed. The CEO believed he needed patience, but Alisa discovered underlying process problems involving an inexperienced product manager and team conflicts. She emphasizes that leaders must distinguish between situations requiring patience versus those needing process intervention, and stay close enough to operations to make this critical distinction.
text_ko: 제가 여러분에게 하고 싶은 말은, 가끔은 인내심이 필요하고, 가끔은 과정을 살펴봐야 한다는 거예요. 그리고 리더로서 여러분은 그 차이를 아는 지혜가 필요하다고 생각해요. 동시에 상황을 잘 파악해서, 이게 인내심의 문제인지 아니면 과정의 문제인지 알아차리는 것도 중요해요.
text_zh: 我想对大家说的是，有时候需要耐心，有时候需要关注过程。作为领导者，我认为你需要具备智慧来分辨两者的不同，同时也要时刻关注情况，以识别这是耐心的问题还是过程的问题。
text_es: Lo que quiero decirles a todos es que a veces es necesario tener paciencia y otras veces hay que enfocarse en el proceso. Creo que, como líder, es fundamental tener la sabiduría para saber la diferencia, pero también estar atento para reconocer si se trata de un problema de paciencia o de proceso.

text: My three questions to end the meeting are, what did we decide here? Who needs to do what by when? And who else needs to know? And if you can capture those, articulate those as deliverables, I promise you, you're going to have better meetings.
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: Lenny asks Alisa about her advice for making meetings more effective. Alisa explains that many meetings fail because there's no continuity between sessions - teams keep re-meeting and re-deciding the same issues. Her three-question framework ensures meetings end with clear outcomes, accountability, and communication plans, preventing the common problem of endless unproductive meeting cycles.
text_ko: 회의를 마치기 전에 제가 묻고 싶은 세 가지 질문이 있어요. 우리가 여기서 무엇을 결정했나요? 누가 언제까지 무엇을 해야 하나요? 그리고 누가 더 알아야 하나요? 이 내용을 잘 정리해서 전달할 수 있다면, 분명 더 나은 회의를 가질 수 있을 거예요.
text_zh: 我结束会议的三个问题是：我们在这里达成了什么决定？谁需要在什么时候完成什么？还有谁需要了解这些？如果你能记录下这些内容，并将其明确为可交付成果，我保证你会有更高效的会议。
text_es: Mis tres preguntas para cerrar la reunión son: ¿qué decidimos aquí? ¿Quién necesita hacer qué y para cuándo? ¿Y quién más debe estar informado? Si puedes capturar eso y articularlo como entregables (deliverables), te prometo que tendrás reuniones más efectivas.

text: According to Noam, Noam Wasserstein, 65% of startups fail because of conflict with founders or the founding team. So it's really essential to get this right, and I agree that people step into this relationship with a lot less care than they should.
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: Lenny introduces Alisa's concept of the 'founder prenup' - a set of questions potential co-founders should discuss before starting a company together. Alisa provides the statistical context showing that founder conflicts are a major cause of startup failure. She emphasizes that people enter co-founder relationships too casually, without doing the necessary work to understand each other's values, goals, and working styles.
vocabulary_highlights: lot less care than they should
text_ko: 노암 워서스타인(Noam Wasserstein)에 따르면, 스타트업의 65%가 창립자나 창립 팀과의 갈등 때문에 실패한다고 해요. 그래서 이 부분을 제대로 챙기는 게 정말 중요해요. 사람들이 이 관계에 대해 생각보다 덜 신경 쓰고 시작하는 것 같아요.
text_zh: 根据诺姆·瓦瑟斯坦（Noam Wasserstein）的说法，65%的初创企业因创始人或创始团队之间的冲突而失败。因此，妥善处理这种关系至关重要。我也同意，人们在进入这种关系时往往缺乏应有的谨慎。
text_es: Según Noam Wasserstein, el 65% de las startups fracasan debido a conflictos entre los fundadores o el equipo fundador. Por lo tanto, es fundamental acertar en esto, y estoy de acuerdo en que las personas entran en esta relación con mucho menos cuidado del que deberían.

text: I got onto the floor, my hardwood floors in my Brookline condo, and I just balled in the fetal position. I just balled and balled and balled for an hour. It wasn't 10 minutes, it was an hour. And I was so frightened and just upset. Am I going to be able to make this work?
speaker: Alisa Cohn
context: During the 'Fail Corner' segment, Lenny asks Alisa to share a personal failure story. Alisa describes a rock bottom moment when she was starting her coaching practice and had a conversation that didn't go well. She shares her vulnerable moment of crying on the floor for an hour, questioning whether she could make her business work, before eventually picking herself up and continuing to take action.
text_ko: 저는 브룩라인 콘도의 나무 바닥에 무릎을 꿇고 fetal position(태아 자세)으로 웅크리고 있었어요. 한 시간 동안 계속 울었어요. 10분이 아니라 정말 한 시간 동안이었죠. 너무 무섭고 속상했어요. 이걸 잘 해낼 수 있을까?
text_zh: 我躺在布鲁克莱恩公寓的木地板上，蜷缩成 fetal position（胎儿姿势），哭了整整一个小时。不是十分钟，而是一个小时。我感到非常害怕和沮丧。我能否让这一切成功呢？
text_es: Me tiré al suelo, en el piso de madera de mi condominio en Brookline, y simplemente me acurruqué en posición fetal. Lloré y lloré durante una hora. No fueron 10 minutos, fueron una hora. Estaba tan asustado y molesto. ¿Voy a poder hacer que esto funcione?
